intro: Anthericum ustulatum var. ciliatum, commonly known as the hairy broadleaf fern, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Araliaceae family and is characterized by its distinctive, broad, ciliate (fringed) leaf margins. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its leaves are large, pinnately compound, and often have a waxy appearance. It produces small, greenish-white flowers in clusters, which are followed by bright red berries that are an important food source for birds.
